questions.text: Which of the following is the mode of genome replication in AIDS virus?
questions.explanation: The AIDS virus, HIV, replicates its genome through the process of reverse transcription, where RNA is converted to DNA, which is then used to produce new RNA genomes.

questions.text: Select the alternative that contains only vector borne infections
options: Leprosy, ring worm, Pneumonia, hook worm
questions.explanation: Malaria, Leishmaniasis, Trypanosomiasis, and Typhus are all vector-borne infections, transmitted by mosquitoes, sandflies, tsetse flies, and lice/fleas respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following groups probably ate more of herbivorous diet?
questions.explanation: Australopithecus afarensis is known to have a diet that included more herbivorous components compared to the other hominid groups listed.

questions.text: Which of the following disease of animal would be controlled if one is able to control tse tse fly?
questions.explanation: Trypanosomiasis, also known as sleeping sickness in humans and nagana in animals, is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

questions.text: In Ethiopia, which of the following genera of microorganisms has the potential to be used for single cell protein production?
questions.explanation: Spirulina is a genus of blue-green algae that can be used for single cell protein production due to its high protein content.

questions.text: Choose the one in which the disease and its categorical names are mismatched?
questions.explanation: Senile dementia is not a deficiency disease; it is a degenerative disease.

questions.text: In which Ethiopian traditional food preparation is the action microorganisms least evident?
questions.explanation: Kinche making involves the least action of microorganisms compared to the fermentation processes involved in making injera, kocho, and yoghurt.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics of life is not possessed by virus?
questions.explanation: Viruses do not possess their own metabolism and do not respire; they rely on the host cell for replication.

questions.text: If culture of green is exposed to light of different colors one at a time, which colors generate more oxygen?
questions.explanation: Blue and red light are most effective for photosynthesis, as they are absorbed by chlorophyll and used to generate oxygen.

questions.text: The bird flu is currently threatening the global poultry industry. What is the causative agent of this disease?
questions.explanation: The causative agent of bird flu is a virus, specifically the influenza A virus subtype H5N1.

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative agent of AIDS?
questions.explanation: The causative agent of AIDS is a virus, specifically the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV).

questions.text: Which of the following can be one reason for the difficulty to produce a vaccine again HIV / AIDS?
options: The small size of the virus
The high variability of the virus
Its possession of RNA instead of DNA
The presence of protective envelope derived from the host cell
questions.explanation: The high variability and mutation rate of HIV make it difficult to produce an effective vaccine.

questions.text: If all dogs in your community are vaccinated, which of the following diseases will be put under control in your community?
questions.explanation: Vaccinating dogs helps control rabies, as dogs are a common vector for the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is mechanism by which bacteriophages transfer genes from one bacterium to another?
questions.explanation: Transduction is the process by which bacteriophages transfer genes from one bacterium to another.

questions.text: If HIV patients take a drug that inhibits the function of the viral reverse transcriptase enzyme which of the following processes would be primarily affected?
options: Entry of the virus into the patient’s body
questions.explanation: Inhibiting reverse transcriptase affects the copying of viral RNA into DNA, a crucial step in HIV replication.

questions.text: Anti HIV/AIDS clubs are today common in schools and colleges, what is the main contribution in the fight against the pandemic?
options: Encourage the girls to have the boy friends
Encourage the boys to have girlfriends
Raise awareness about the problem among students
questions.explanation: Anti HIV/AIDS clubs primarily raise awareness about the disease and its prevention among students.

questions.text: Some countries demand foreign travelers to produce HIV/AIDS free certificate before letting them enter the country What do we call this type of disease control mechanism?
questions.explanation: Requiring HIV/AIDS free certificates for entry is a legislative measure to control the spread of the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about HIV?
options: It infects pants and animals alike
questions.explanation: HIV is a retrovirus, meaning it has RNA as its genetic material and uses reverse transcriptase to replicate.

questions.text: Select the kingdom of life in which cellular organelles are without membrane around them?
questions.explanation: Monera, which includes bacteria, have cellular organelles without membranes around them.

questions.text: Identify from the following a biological control method of malaria?
options: Use of fishes to feed on mosquito larvae
Use of DDT spraying to kill mosquitoes
Using crop rotation system in farm
Hand picking and physical removal of weeds and affected plants
questions.explanation: Using fishes to feed on mosquito larvae is a biological control method for malaria.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about meanings contained in the in the name HIV and AIDs?
options: HIV refers to symptoms that characterize the condition
AIDS refers to the causative agent
HIV refers to the probable origin from the chimpanzee
questions.explanation: AIDS (Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome) refers to the symptoms and conditions that characterize the advanced stage of HIV infection.

questions.text: Identify the disease that is not correctly paired with the substance whose deficiency causes the disease?
questions.explanation: Beriberi is caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1), not nicotinic acid.

questions.text: Of the following, which cell type is attacked by HIV?
questions.explanation: HIV primarily attacks T helper cells (CD4 cells), which are a type of white blood cell crucial for the immune system.

questions.text: If one regularly includes orange in his daily diet, which deficiency disease would be avoided?
questions.explanation: Oranges are rich in vitamin C, which helps prevent scurvy.

questions.text: Which of the following disease of livestock is associated with tsetse flies?
questions.explanation: Trypanosomiasis, also known as nagana, is a disease of livestock transmitted by tsetse flies.

questions.text: What are the causes of infectious disease?
questions.explanation: Infectious diseases are caused by microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites.

questions.text: Among the following human diseases, identify the one that is transmitted through a vector?
questions.explanation: Leishmaniasis is transmitted through the bite of infected sandflies, which are vectors.

questions.text: A number of virus including HIV, have more than one strain. This show the viruses are;
options: Capable of living outside their host cell
questions.explanation: The existence of multiple strains indicates that viruses are capable of mutation.

questions.text: Which is not true of prokaryotes? They
questions.explanation: Not all prokaryotes are parasites; many are free-living and play essential roles in ecosystems.

questions.text: Which of the following are rod shaped bacteria?
questions.explanation: Bacilli are rod-shaped bacteria.

questions.text: The cells of which group of microorganisms can be described as prokaryotic?
questions.explanation: Bacteria are prokaryotic, meaning they lack a true nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles.

questions.text: What are bacteriophages?
questions.explanation: Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria.

questions.text: Which of the following is major killer of AIDS patients?
questions.explanation: Opportunistic infections are a major cause of death in AIDS patients due to their weakened immune systems.

questions.text: Among the following infectious human diseases, identify the one that is caused by a virus?
questions.explanation: Yellow fever is caused by a virus.

questions.text: Why T lymphocytes more vulnerable to HIV infection?
options: Because they posses thin cell membrane
Large pores in their cell membrane
questions.explanation: T lymphocytes are more vulnerable to HIV infection because they have gp120 receptors on their surface, which HIV uses to enter the cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about bacteria?
options: Bacteria found in human body are all parasitic
all bacteria are harmful because they spoil food
all bacteria cause disease to humans, plants, and animals in some ways
some bacteria living in human body make vitamins needed by the body
questions.explanation: Some bacteria in the human body produce vitamins, such as vitamin K and certain B vitamins, which are essential for health.

questions.text: Which one of the following is mode of reproduction in bacteria?
questions.explanation: Binary fission is the primary mode of reproduction in bacteria.

questions.text: If AIDS patient given antiretroviral drugs are targeted against the protease enzyme, which one of the following stages of the HIV life cycle would be inhibited
options: Integration of viral DNA into host DNA
Assembly of viral parts into a whole virus
questions.explanation: Protease inhibitors prevent the assembly of viral parts into a whole virus by inhibiting the protease enzyme.

questions.text: Which of the following I true about those bacteria which dwell in hot spring?
options: they get energy of activation from the spring heat
their enzymes do not denature at the temperature
questions.explanation: Bacteria that dwell in hot springs have enzymes that do not denature at high temperatures, allowing them to remain metabolically active.

questions.text: Choose the disease that is caused by what is known as the droplet infection?
questions.explanation: Flu is caused by droplet infection, where the virus is transmitted through respiratory droplets.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best collective name for all bacteria with spherical shape?
questions.explanation: Cocci is the collective name for all bacteria with a spherical shape.

questions.text: In which part of the cell do gram positive and gram negative bacteria differ regarding their staining property with gram stains?
questions.explanation: Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria differ in their cell wall structure, which affects their staining properties with Gram stains.

questions.text: To which of the following does HIV belong?
questions.explanation: HIV belongs to the group of retroviruses.

questions.text: What are the individual strands of fungal mycelium called?
questions.explanation: The individual strands of fungal mycelium are called hyphae.

questions.text: What is the mode of transmission of diseases such as cholera and typhoid fever?
questions.explanation: Cholera and typhoid fever are transmitted through drinking contaminated water.

questions.text: Viruses are better characterized as:
questions.explanation: Viruses are better characterized as parasites because they rely on host cells for replication.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the antiretroviral drugs currently used to treat AIDS patient?
options: They serve as anti HIV vaccine
questions.explanation: Antiretroviral drugs slow down HIV multiplication, helping to manage the infection.

questions.text: What are the most frequent causative agents of food poisoning?
questions.explanation: Bacteria are the most frequent causative agents of food poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following practice does not normally transmit HIV?
questions.explanation: Shaking hands does not normally transmit HIV.

questions.text: Which of the following human diseases can be prevented by taking proper diet?
questions.explanation: Deficiency diseases can be prevented by taking a proper diet that includes all necessary nutrients.

questions.text: To which of the following groups do those bacteriophages that integrate their DNA into the chromosomes of their bacterial host belong?
questions.explanation: Bacteriophages that integrate their DNA into the chromosomes of their bacterial host are known as lysogenic viruses.

questions.text: Which groups of microorganisms causes disease known as athlete’s foot?
questions.explanation: Athlete's foot is caused by fungi, specifically dermatophytes.

questions.text: Choose the one which is different from the others?
questions.explanation: Pathogenic organisms are different from the others as they are organisms that cause disease, while the others refer to organisms that have been genetically altered.

questions.text: What is the advantage of using HAART for treatment of HIV?
options: It gives lasting immunity to HIV
It prevents re infection by HIV
It helps to break the life cycle of HIV
questions.explanation: HAART (Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy) helps to break the life cycle of HIV by using a combination of drugs that target different stages of the virus's replication.

questions.text: On which one of the following principles is most of anti HIV drugs currently in use working?
questions.explanation: Most anti-HIV drugs work by inhibiting the action of enzymes crucial for viral replication, such as reverse transcriptase and protease.

questions.text: If a new anti HIV drug is to be developed to prevent the virus from entering the host cell, which one of the following processes should the drug target?
options: Integration of viral DNA in to host DNA
Assembly of viral parts in to whole virus
questions.explanation: A drug aimed at preventing the virus from entering the host cell should target the bonding of Gp120 and CD4, which is the process by which HIV attaches to and enters host cells.

questions.text: Which of the following groups of bacteria consists of rod shaped?
questions.explanation: Bacilli are rod-shaped bacteria.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about protozoa?
options: they represent both plants and animals
questions.explanation: Protozoa are unicellular animals.

questions.text: Which of the following do viruses share with the cell?
questions.explanation: Viruses share nucleic acid with cells, as they contain either DNA or RNA.

questions.text: Choose the characteristics that viruses share with living things?
options: they are made up of many specialized cells
questions.explanation: Viruses contain genetic materials, which is a characteristic they share with living things.

questions.text: Which stage in the life cycle of HIV inhibited by the anti-retro viral drug known as integrase inhibitor?
options: Conversion of viral RNA to DNA
Insertion of the viral genome into host genome
Release of viral progeny from the cell
questions.explanation: Integrase inhibitors inhibit the insertion of the viral genome into the host genome.

questions.text: What is the difference between HIV and AIDS?
options: AIDS is the virus and HIV is the disease
Both AIDS and HIV refers to the disease
AIDS is the disease and HIV is the virus
Both AIDS and HIV refers to the virus
questions.explanation: AIDS is the disease caused by the virus HIV.

questions.text: What does the absence of chloroplast in unicellular organisms indicate?
questions.explanation: The absence of chloroplasts in unicellular organisms indicates heterotrophic nutrition, as they cannot perform photosynthesis.

questions.text: What the color do gram positive bacteria stain with gram stains?
questions.explanation: Gram-positive bacteria stain purple with Gram stains.

questions.text: Among the following organisms which one belongs to the prokaryotes?
questions.explanation: Streptococcus is a prokaryote, as it is a bacterium.

questions.text: What is the process called when two bacteria directly contact cell to cell and exchange their genetic information?
questions.explanation: Conjugation is the process where two bacteria directly contact cell to cell and exchange their genetic information.

questions.text: Which of the following features makes humans T- lymphocyte cells more vulnerable to HIV attack? Presence of
questions.explanation: The presence of CD4 on the membrane surface makes T-lymphocyte cells more vulnerable to HIV attack.

questions.text: In which of the following ways retro virus differ from the other RNA viruses?
options: They copy RNA to DNA molecule
They copy RNA from DNA molecule
questions.explanation: Retroviruses differ from other RNA viruses by copying RNA to DNA molecules.

questions.text: Which of the following groups of microorganisms does not contain parasitic members?
questions.explanation: Algae do not contain parasitic members; they are primarily photosynthetic organisms.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the smallest of all?
questions.explanation: Viruses are the smallest of all, typically ranging from 20 to 300 nanometers in size.

questions.text: Which of the following is the routine method used by clinics to test people for HIV infection?
options: counting the number of white blood cells
testing for human anti HIV antibody
questions.explanation: The routine method used by clinics to test people for HIV infection is testing for human anti-HIV antibodies.

questions.text: The T- lymphocyte cells of AIDS patients are destroyed by
options: Multiplication of HIV inside the cell
The immune system of the host organisms itself
The CD4 receptors on the cell surface
questions.explanation: The T-lymphocyte cells of AIDS patients are destroyed by the multiplication of HIV inside the cell.

questions.text: Which stage of the lifecycle of HIV is disrupted if AIDS patients are with drug that has a protease inhibiting activity?
options: Entry of the virus into the host
Conversion of viral RNA to DNA
Integration of viral DNA into host DNA
Assembly of viral parts into whole virus
questions.explanation: Protease inhibitors disrupt the assembly of viral parts into a whole virus.

questions.text: One of the following is true about bacteriophages that have lysogenic life cycle?
options: They integrate their nucleic acid in to that of the host
They multiply in the host immediately after infection
Pathogen viruses are release by chronic release method
questions.explanation: Bacteriophages with a lysogenic life cycle integrate their nucleic acid into that of the host.

questions.text: Which of the following type if cancer is known to mostly develop in AIDS patient?
questions.explanation: Kaposi's sarcoma is a type of cancer that mostly develops in AIDS patients.

questions.text: In which of the following living organisms do the cells lack organized nuclei?
questions.explanation: Bacteria lack organized nuclei; they are prokaryotes.

questions.text: Which of the following is major mechanism by which AIDS is transmitted?
questions.explanation: Heterosexual intercourse is a major mechanism by which AIDS is transmitted.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is correctly matched with its causative agent?
questions.explanation: AIDS is correctly matched with its causative agent, which is a virus.

questions.text: Which step in HIV life cycle is disrupted by antiretroviral drug that competitively inhibits transcriptase enzyme?
options: assembly of viral parts into a virus
Integration of viral DNA into host DNA
questions.explanation: Antiretroviral drugs that competitively inhibit transcriptase enzyme disrupt the formation of DNA from RNA.

questions.text: In what way would AIDS patient benefits from treatment with antiretroviral drugs?
questions.explanation: AIDS patients benefit from treatment with antiretroviral drugs through the reduction of HIV replication.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best collective name for all bacteria with spherical shape?
questions.explanation: Cocci is the best collective name for all bacteria with a spherical shape.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is transmitted by mosquito?
questions.explanation: Malaria is transmitted by mosquitoes.

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms are prokaryotic?
questions.explanation: Bacteria are prokaryotic microorganisms.

questions.text: Form which of the following diseases can one be protected by sleeping under the cover of mosquito net?
questions.explanation: One can be protected from malaria by sleeping under the cover of a mosquito net.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest risk of HIV transmission?
questions.explanation: Needle sharing has the highest risk of HIV transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs during dark reaction of photosynthesis?
questions.explanation: During the dark reaction of photosynthesis, NADPH is synthesized.

questions.text: Which of the following human cell type is attacked by HIV?
questions.explanation: HIV primarily attacks T-lymphocytes (CD4 cells).

questions.text: Among the following which one best describes the cells of bacteria?
questions.explanation: Bacteria cells are best described as prokaryotic.

questions.text: Which of the following groups of viruses copy their RNA to DNA?
questions.explanation: Retroviruses copy their RNA to DNA.

questions.text: What is the name of a major group of eukaryotic organisms that obtain their nutrition using extracellular digestion?
questions.explanation: Fungi are a major group of eukaryotic organisms that obtain their nutrition using extracellular digestion.

questions.text: In what main ways do retroviruses such as HIV differ from other type of RNA viruses?
options: They require a host cell to reproduce
They reversely copy RNA to DNA
Their genes are resistance to mutation
questions.explanation: Retroviruses such as HIV differ from other RNA viruses by reversely copying RNA to DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following is taken as a signal for the final stage of HIV infection?
options: Signs of a disease kaposi’s sarcoma
No infection by other parasitic diseases
questions.explanation: The final stage of HIV infection is signaled by the onset of diseases such as Kaposi's sarcoma.

questions.text: In which organ of human body are more bacteria found?
questions.explanation: More bacteria are found in the large intestine.

questions.text: From which groups of microorganisms the first antibiotics produced?
questions.explanation: The first antibiotics were produced from fungal organisms, specifically Penicillium.

questions.text: The best way to control HIV/AIDS is
questions.explanation: The best way to control HIV/AIDS is through awareness creation and education.

questions.text: Which of the following is essential in order for a virus replication?
options: The capsid must enter the host cell cytoplasm
The host cell must be undergoing mitosis
The host cell must lack cell membrane
the genome must be released into the cytoplasm
questions.explanation: For virus replication, the genome must be released into the cytoplasm of the host cell.

questions.text: Retroviruses are able to reverse transcribe RNA to DNA in order to
options: command the host cell in the production of genomes similar to that of the host
Control the formation of viral protein and RNA that can be assembled in to new viruses practices
Control the formation of viral protein and DNA that can be assembled into new viral practice
questions.explanation: Retroviruses reverse transcribe RNA to DNA to control the formation of viral protein and RNA that can be assembled into new viruses.

questions.text: In which of the following groups of organisms are all the members of unicellular?
questions.explanation: All members of bacteria are unicellular.

questions.text: Which clinical test is routinely performed to diagnose patient for AIDS?
options: Serological test for anti HIV antibody
culturing the virus on a special media
questions.explanation: The serological test for anti-HIV antibody is routinely performed to diagnose patients for AIDS.

questions.text: Which one of the following human disease is not correctly matched with its mode of transmission?
questions.explanation: Sleeping sickness is transmitted by the tsetse fly (vector), not by physical contact.

questions.text: In what way does an antiretroviral drug help AIDS patient? It
options: Stimulates the multiplication of T- helper cells
questions.explanation: Antiretroviral drugs help AIDS patients by stopping the multiplication of HIV.

questions.text: What is capsid?
options: The protein shell of a virus
The genetic material of a virus
questions.explanation: The capsid is the protein shell of a virus.

questions.text: From which group of microorganisms was the first antibiotic produced?
questions.explanation: The first antibiotic, penicillin, was produced from members of the fungi, specifically Penicillium.

questions.text: What is the main method of transmission of botulism?
questions.explanation: The main method of transmission of botulism is eating contaminated food.

questions.text: Transfer of gene or genes through virus is called
questions.explanation: Transfer of genes or genes through a virus is called transduction.

questions.text: When reverse transcriptase a useful enzyme? When
options: There are no host cells present
RNA virus converts its RNA to DNA
The virus is in the lytic cycle
questions.explanation: Reverse transcriptase is a useful enzyme when an RNA virus converts its RNA to DNA.

questions.text: Spikes are forming in the new virus. In what ways does retro virus differ from other RNA viruses?
questions.explanation: Retroviruses differ from other RNA viruses by copying RNA to DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement about the difference between bacterium and virus?
options: DNA is present in the former, but absent in the later
Protein is absent in the former, but present in the later
The former is cellular, but the latter is acellular
The former causes malaria, but the later causes cholera
questions.explanation: Bacteria are cellular organisms, while viruses are acellular.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not correct?
options: HIV – positive people are forced by law to disclose their HIV status
Employers may not dismiss an employee because of his /her HIV status
There is no medication that can reduce your chance of contracting HIV
Mothers can give their babies by means of breast feeding
questions.explanation: There is medication that can reduce the chance of contracting HIV, such as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP).

questions.text: Which one of the following happens during integration of viruses into host cells?
options: The viral DNA is inserted into the host DNA
The viral DNA inters the host cell
The virus attaches to the hoist cell receptor
The virus takes over the host cells machinery
questions.explanation: During integration, the viral DNA is inserted into the host DNA.
